snippet.textDisplay:
@BeleuchteteBrueder Both CT and CC soundtracks are awesome. As for CC, another thing is that it isn't like CT at all. Both are rpgs of an unusual kind, especially CC. But I never heard any real rpg fan denying that it remains a masterpiece of the PS1 (even if I prefer FF7/Xenogears/Valkyrie Profile/SuikodenII).
Do CT by any means, without spoiling yourself, it suits almost everyone and it's very addictive.
snippet.textOriginal:
@BeleuchteteBrueder Both CT and CC soundtracks are awesome. As for CC, another thing is that it isn't like CT at all. Both are rpgs of an unusual kind, especially CC. But I never heard any real rpg fan denying that it remains a masterpiece of the PS1 (even if I prefer FF7/Xenogears/Valkyrie Profile/SuikodenII).
Do CT by any means, without spoiling yourself, it suits almost everyone and it's very addictive.

snippet.textDisplay: @xenotypos Oh, I wouldn't have thought so. Even though I know that CC has a decent soundtrack I heard from most people that they were dissapointed for the most part by the game itself. Personally, I haven't played either of them, I only recently bought CT for Virtual Console.
snippet.textOriginal: @xenotypos Oh, I wouldn't have thought so. Even though I know that CC has a decent soundtrack I heard from most people that they were dissapointed for the most part by the game itself. Personally, I haven't played either of them, I only recently bought CT for Virtual Console.

snippet.textDisplay: @xenotypos Well, alright, you might have taken my words too literally. Of course the series is not unique in this regard. There are others, espacially Final Fantasy. You can take my words and use them for those games, too. I did not want to say that Zelda is the greatest franchise of all time, I just wanted to point out that is is astonishing how random it seems to be which title is prefered by whom. And Zelda is special about that. Not unique, but special. It's a notworthy thing. With almost every game series you have debates over which title is the best, but there seems to be a lot more consistency about other franchises. Final Fantasy - OK - this really is another good example.  But are there really people out there who think that Chrono Cross is superior to Chrono Trigger? :)
snippet.textOriginal: @xenotypos Well, alright, you might have taken my words too literally. Of course the series is not unique in this regard. There are others, espacially Final Fantasy. You can take my words and use them for those games, too. With almost every game series you have debates over which title is the best, but there seems to be a lot more consistency about other franchises. Final Fantasy - OK - this really is another good example.  But are there really people out there who think that Chrono Cross is superior to Chrono Trigger? :)

snippet.textDisplay:
@BeleuchteteBrueder" I still think this is more true with the Zelda series than with any other. Every Zelda title has it's die hard fans and people who dislike it"

That's precisely what I said: It's just that you prefer this series or because you know it more. The most random topic of all time in video games is "what is your favorite Final Fantasy". The reply always differ, FF4, 6, 7, 8, 9 and even 10 ans 12 have their huge lot of fans. How is it possible to say that one is better than the other? How would it be possible too with other series like Tales of, Suikoden (2? 3? 5?), Xenogears/saga/blade, Chrono Trigger/Chrono Cross etc etc

You just think there is something special with Zelda because you like this series. And by that I mean, that's really the only reason, seriously.
Of course, I don't talk about FPS, action games, sport games, fighting games... for those i agree it's different, it's just a matter of genre.
snippet.textOriginal:
@BeleuchteteBrueder" I still think this is more true with the Zelda series than with any other. Every Zelda title has it's die hard fans and people who dislike it"

That's precisely what I said: It's just that you prefer this series or because you know it more. The most random topic of all time in video games is "what is your favorite Final Fantasy". The reply always differ, FF4, 6, 7, 8, 9 and even 10 ans 12 have their huge lot of fans. How is it possible to say that one is better than the other? How would it be possible too with other series like Tales of, Suikoden (2? 3? 5?), Xenogears/saga/blade, Chrono Trigger/Chrono Cross etc etc

You just think there is something special with Zelda because you like this series. And by that I mean, that's really the only reason, seriously.
Of course, I don't talk about FPS, action games, sport games, fighting games... for those i agree it's different, it's just a matter of genre.

snippet.textDisplay: @xenotypos I think I made my point two comments above. It's a different experience for everyone. I still think this is more true with the Zelda series than with any other. Every Zelda title has it's die hard fans and people who dislike it. Are some of them are more right than the others...? I don't know. To me, Skyward Sword was by far the best Zelda since Majora's Mask. You can find good arguments for each side, but in the end it all comes down to those who prefer a certain atmosphere, those who need a well crafted overworld (something, The Wind Waker definitely lacks) and those who need clever dungeons and puzzles. I could write a book about why The Wind Waker was a huge dissapointment, why Twilight Princess was ambitious, but massivley flawed, why Majora's Mask is one of the best games of all time and why Skyward Sword is exactly what I hoped for in a successor to the series. So of course there are certain points any of us can make. I am merely stating that obviusly, with this series, there is something special going :)
snippet.textOriginal: @xenotypos I think I made my point two comments above. It's a different experience for everyone. I still think this is more true with the Zelda series than with any other. Every Zelda title has it's die hard fans and people who dislike it. Are some of them are more right than the others...? I don't know. To me, Skyward Sword was by far the best Zelda since Majora's Mask. You can find good arguments for each side, but in the end it all comes down to those who prefer a certain atmosphere, those who need a well crafted overworld (something, The Wind Waker definitely lacks) and those who need clever dungeons and puzzles. I could write a book about why The Wind Waker was a huge dissapointment, why Twilight Princess was ambitious, but massivley flawed, why Majora's Mask is one of the best games of all time and why Skyward Sword is exactly what I hoped for in a successor to the series. So of course there are certain points any of us can make. I am merely stating that obviusly, with this series, there is something special going :)

snippet.textDisplay:
@BeleuchteteBrueder Dude what the hell are you talking about, this game is amazing. Zelda WW is one my two favorite 3d Zelda games with Ocarina of Time. The worst 3D Zelda is by far Skyward Sword, but I have to say that TP was too much like OoT for me to appreciate it fully. As for Majora's Mask, it's probably the only Zelda with a good storyline but I still prefer OoT and WW because they are more Zelda-like, with this incredible feeling of adventure, whether it is on the hyrule plains or on the seas.
Anyway, I don't see why Zelda would be more difficult to evaluate than most games, seeing the strength and flaws of each. It's probably more difficult with many Jrpg. The only thing is, every of thoses games are personnal expériences, so of course the feeling is different.
snippet.textOriginal:
@BeleuchteteBrueder Dude what the hell are you talking about, this game is amazing. Zelda WW is one my two favorite 3d Zelda games with Ocarina of Time. The worst 3D Zelda is by far Skyward Sword, but I have to say that TP was too much like OoT for me to appreciate it fully. As for Majora's Mask, it's probably the only Zelda with a good storyline but I still prefer OoT and WW because they are more Zelda-like, with this incredible feeling of adventure, whether it is on the hyrule plains or on the seas.
Anyway, I don't see why Zelda would be more difficult to evaluate than most games, seeing the strength and flaws of each. It's probably more difficult with many Jrpg. The only thing is, every of thoses games are personnal expériences, so of course the feeling is different.

snippet.textDisplay: @BeleuchteteBrueder  Dude, I LOVE the entire Zelda series. It's definitely Nintendo's staple series, if you ask me. Although, IMO, Majora's Mask was too dark. On a technical standpoint, it was amazing, but I didn't enjoy it. Wind Waker was a little more light-hearted in that regard. I think that is why I enjoyed it the most out of any Zelda, because the feeling of adventuring and exploring was a lot more apparent than in Majora's Mask, where you were sorta on a clock the whole time. Also, the theme of the entire world ending if you weren't quick enough. I just don't think it fits with the theme of Zelda. But that's just me. Majora's Mask was still amazing, and technically one of the greatest games of all time.
snippet.textOriginal: @BeleuchteteBrueder  Dude, I LOVE the entire Zelda series. It's definitely Nintendo's staple series, if you ask me. Although, IMO, Majora's Mask was too dark. On a technical standpoint, it was amazing, but I didn't enjoy it. Wind Waker was a little more light-hearted in that regard. I think that is why I enjoyed it the most out of any Zelda, because the feeling of adventuring and exploring was a lot more apparent than in Majora's Mask, where you were sorta on a clock the whole time. Also, the theme of the entire world ending if you weren't quick enough. I just don't think it fits with the theme of Zelda. But that's just me. Majora's Mask was still amazing, and technically one of the greatest games of all time.

snippet.textDisplay: Yes, of course experiences differ with each person, but I think that with Zelda games that is even more ture. With many other games you can see obvious flaws and strenghts, but Zelda is different. Maybe that says something about the quality of the series in general, maybe it says something about the kind of game Zelda is - a highly immersive, personal experience that resonates differently in each and every one of us. And we have huge expectations when it comes to Zelda games. To me, Majora's Mask was the greatest gaming experience of all time. And you have to give huge respect to the Zelda team for creating such a unique title every time (in terms of how the game is played and designed) instead of just blindly copying the successful formula.
snippet.textOriginal: Yes, of course experiences differ with each person, but I think that with Zelda games that is even more ture. With many other games you can see obvious flaws and strenghts, but Zelda is different. Maybe that says something about the quality of the series in general, maybe it says something about the kind of game Zelda is - a highly immersive, personal experience that resonates differently in each and every one of us. And we have huge expectations when it comes to Zelda games. To me, Majora's Mask was the greatest gaming experience of all time. And you have to give huge respect to the Zelda team for creating such a unique title every time (in terms of how the game is played and designed) instead of just blindly copying the successful formula.

snippet.textDisplay: @TheDannyMan It just felt pretty rushed in development. The promise of a huge sea with islands to explore was not fulfilled. Alsmost every island was a useless spot of grass with a few rupees, the world felt strangely empty and lifeless. I was looking forward to a game of true exploration that combined the idea of Zelda with sea exploration. The bosses were pretty underwhelming and ridiculously easy and they did not live up to the potential of telling the story of a flooded Hyrule. There were a few great moments, but it was just glimpses of what game could have been. I did like the art stlye and the soundtrack, though. And the final battle was nicley excecuted. But after ALttP, OoT and MM, it was just a huge dissapointment.
snippet.textOriginal: @TheDannyMan It just felt pretty rushed in development. The promise of a huge sea with islands to explore was not fulfilled. Alsmost every island was a useless spot of grass with a few rupees, the world felt strangely empty and lifeless. I was looking forward to a game of true exploration that combined the idea of Zelda with sea exploration. The bosses were pretty underwhelming and ridiculously easy and they did not live up to the potential of telling the story of a flooded Hyrule. There were a few great moments, but it was just glimpses of what game could have been. I did like the art stlye and the soundtrack, though. And the final battle was nicley excecuted. But after ALttP, OoT and MM, it was just a huge dissapointment.

snippet.textDisplay:
@ninds7 Oh no, it's fine. I didn't fully realize how realistic my comment was. I thought it would be obvious that electric guitar and dubstep would not only be terrible, but dubstep became big only recently. This disregards the fact that people are out there that would actually not take this into consideration though, and be dumb like that.

So thanks for an actual, genuine sorry. That's rare on the internet. I understand though. It's no big deal anyway, just youtube comment nonsense. :)
snippet.textOriginal:
@ninds7 Oh no, it's fine. I didn't fully realize how realistic my comment was. Undoubtely, the perfect song to end the perfect game.

snippet.textDisplay: @LinkTetraWW Definitely.  It's so amazing how well the three main tunes of this game mesh so well together, that they create such an impressive harmony.  I thought that OoT and TP also did a solid job of mixing the tunes together, but no game in the series comes as close to just a perfect symphonic consistency like WW.
snippet.textOriginal: @LinkTetraWW Definitely.  It's so amazing how well the three main tunes of this game mesh so well together, that they create such an impressive harmony.  I thought that OoT and TP also did a solid job of mixing the tunes together, but no game in the series comes as close to just a perfect symphonic consistency like WW.

snippet.textDisplay: Great pick. I always found two WW themes very memorable: the mini-boss theme and especially the Molgera theme. They managed to capture the exciting feel of battle, but by using instruments you won't often find in songs that try to create that same feeling. Yet it works so well.
snippet.textOriginal: Great pick. I always found two WW themes very memorable: the mini-boss theme and especially the Molgera theme. They managed to capture the exciting feel of battle, but by using instruments you won't often find in songs that try to create that same feeling. Yet it works so well.

snippet.textDisplay:
@SupraDarky Only problem is the Wii is ruining the heritage of the LoZ series. I don't give a damn if it "feel's weird" to people to swing with a remote and see opposite on a screen, simple adjustments to the game can fix that. Link is and always should be LEFT HANDED! By portraying him as a righty it ruins what made link unique.

Some may think thats petty, obviously newer younger gamers that haven't been there from the get go, even the special magazine NP made about the series points it out
snippet.textOriginal:
@SupraDarky Only problem is the Wii is ruining the heritage of the LoZ series. I don't give a damn if it "feel's weird" to people to swing with a remote and see opposite on a screen, simple adjustments to the game can fix that. Link is and always should be LEFT HANDED! By portraying him as a righty it ruins what made link unique.

Some may think thats petty, obviously newer younger gamers that haven't been there from the get go, even the special magazine NP made about the series points it out

snippet.textDisplay:
@ninds7 Oh man, I was being completely sarcastic. Oh, that's lame. I totally forgot that that kind of a comment is usually serious and that dumb. I probably should've made it a whole lot more obvious. 

But yes, Wind Waker is an amazing game, and this is an amazing credits music. It sends chills down my spine, and it's use of common zelda melodies is executed amazingly and appropriately. I just thought that was going to be the common post, so I thought I'd make a sarcastic joke.
snippet.textOriginal:
@ninds7 Oh man, I was being completely sarcastic. Oh, that's lame. I totally forgot that that kind of a comment is usually serious and that dumb. I probably should've made it a whole lot more obvious.

"Staff Roll" = "Credits", I guess?  I learned something today.

"Staff Roll" = "Credits", I guess?  I learned something today.
